questions.text: TBUT (tear break-Up Time) employs which of the following dye?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fluorescein Seidel’s test. The tear film is stained to detect leakage of aqueous from the anterior chamber in the postoperative shallow anterior chamber, perforating trauma, and perforation of corneal ulcer. Rigid contact lens fitting is best judged with the fluorescein pattern of the tear film.

Highyeild:

Seidel’s test. The tear film is stained to detect leakage of aqueous from the anterior chamber in the postoperative shallow anterior chamber, perforating trauma, and perforation of corneal ulcer. Rigid contact lens fitting is best judged with the fluorescein pattern of the tear film.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Rose Bengal staining is a very useful test for detecting even mild cases of KCS. Depending upon the severity of KCS three staining patterns A, B, and C have been described: ‘C’ pattern represents mild or early cases with fine punctate stains in the interpalpebral area; ‘B’ the moderate cases with extensive staining; and ‘A’ the severe cases with confluent staining of conjunctiva and cornea.

Extraedge:

Intravenous fluorescein (10% and 25%) is used for: Fundus fluorescein angiography Iris angiography for evaluation of the vasculature Vitreous fluorophotometry.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female presents with chronic itchiness, mucoid discharge and foreign body sensation. Her tear film breakup time (BUT) is less than 10 seconds. Which of the following treatment modalities is not appropriate?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antihistaminic drops The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of dry eye . There is no role for antihistaminic drops in this condition.

Highyeild:

Lacrimal tests include tear film break-up time (TFBUT) for any eye and Jane’s test for watering the eye. TFBUT measurement is an easy and fast method used to assess the stability of tear film. It is a standard diagnostic procedure in dry eye clinics. Tear film break-up time is abnormal in several conditions like aqueous tear deficiency [2], keratoconjunctivitis sicca, mucin deficiency, meibomian gland disorders

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Several varieties of effective artificial tears are commercially available and can be effectively used. The slow-release variety is a pellet of a cellulose compound without preservative that is inserted below the tarsus of the lower lid where it dissolves slowly, providing a continuous source of tears. Option: B. Excess mucus may be treated with acetylcysteine 5 percent drops buffered to pH 8.4 with sodium bicarbonate. Option: C. Squamous metaplasia of the ocular surface epithelium may play a part in the production of symptoms. This abnormality can be reversed by the application of topical trans-retinoic acid ointment with the alleviation of discomfort.

Extraedge:

Seidel’s test. The tear film is stained to detect leakage of aqueous from the anterior chamber in the postoperative shallow anterior chamber, perforating trauma, and perforation of corneal ulcer. Rigid contact lens fitting is best judged with the fluorescein pattern of the tear film.

questions.text: Tears are continuously secreted throughout the day and maintained through a constant mechanism of secretion and elimination. Which of these statements is correct about this mechanism?

options.label: A
options.text: Secretion is continuously managed with main (basal secretion) and accessory (reflex secretion) lacrimal glands

options.label: B
options.text: From the lacrimal gland, the tears flow downwards and medially across the ocular surface

options.label: C
options.text: Contraction of preseptal fibers of orbicularis distends the lacrimal sac and creates a negative pressure

options.label: D
options.text: About 30% of tears are drained via the inferior canaliculus

questions.correct_answer: C. Contraction of preseptal fibers of orbicularis distends the lacrimal sac and creates a negative pressure
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Contraction of preseptal fibers of orbicularis distends the lacrimal sac and creates a negative pressure When the eyelids close with each blink there occurs: 1) Contraction of preseptal fibers of orbicularis distends the lacrimal sac and creates a negative pressure that draws the tear fluid from canaliculi into the lacrimal sac. 2) Contraction of pretarsal orbicularis oculi which compresses the ampulla and shortens the canaliculi. This movement propels the tear fluid present in the ampulla and horizontal part of the canaliculi towards the lacrimal sac.

Highyeild:

Tear film break-up time is abnormal in several conditions like aqueous tear deficiency [2], keratoconjunctivitis sicca, mucin deficiency, meibomian gland disorders

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Tears are continuously secreted throughout the day by the accessory (basal secretion) and main (reflex secretion) lacrimal glands. Reflex secretion is in response to sensations from the cornea and conjunctiva, probably produced by evaporation and breakup of the tear film. Option: B . From the lacrimal gland, the tears flow downwards and laterally across the ocular surface. A variable amount of tears is lost by evaporation from the ocular surface. The remainder of the tears flow along the superior and inferior marginal strips and collects as lacus lacrimal in the inner canthus. Option: D. About 70% of tears are drained via the inferior canaliculus and 30% via the superior canaliculus by an active lacrimal pump mechanism constituted by the fibers of the orbicularis

questions.text: A 60-year-old female complains of chronically sore eyes not responding to eye drops. On exam, you notice Froth in the tears along the lid margin. Which of the following test results would be unable to help the diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Marginal tear strip height of 0.5 mm

questions.correct_answer: B. Schirmer-I test value of 18 mm
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schirmer-I test value of 18 mm The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of moderately severe dry eye most probably due to age-related causes. Froth in the tears along the lid margin is a sign of meibomian gland dysfunction . Normal values of the Schirmer-I test are more than 15 mm.

Highyeild:

Values of 5–10 mm are suggestive (but not diagnostic) of moderate to mild keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS) and less than 5 mm of severe KCS .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Tear film break-up (BUT) is the interval between a complete blink and the appearance of the first randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. It is noted after instilling a drop of fluorescein and examining a cobalt-blue light of a slit lamp . But it is an indicator of the adequacy of the mucin component of tears. Its normal values range from 15 to 35 seconds. Values less than 10 seconds imply an unstable tear film. Option: C. Rose Bengal staining is a very useful test for detecting even mild cases of KCS. Depending upon the severity of KCS three staining patterns A, B , and C have been described: ‘C’ pattern represents mild or early cases with fine punctate stains in the interpalpebral area; ‘B’ the moderate cases with extensive staining; and ‘A’ the severe cases with confluent staining of conjunctiva and cornea. Option: D. Marginal tear strip is reduced or absent (normal height is 1 mm) in cases of dry eye. Froth in the tears along the lid margin is a sign of meibomian gland dysfunction.

Extraedge:

Lacrimal tests include tear film break-up time (TFBUT) for any eye and Jane’s test for watering the eye. TFBUT measurement is an easy and fast method used to assess the stability of tear film. It is a standard diagnostic procedure in dry eye clinics. Tear film break-up time is abnormal in several conditions like aqueous tear deficiency [2], keratoconjunctivitis sicca, mucin deficiency, meibomian gland disorders

questions.text: A 70-year-old female presents with watering eyes for 8 days. She reports that she has been suffering from such episodes quite frequently. On exam, you notice the laxity of the lower lid. Which of these is a possible cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Eversion of lower punctum The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of epiphora due to mechanical obstruction 2⁰ to eversion of the lower punctum. It is commonly seen in old age due to the laxity of the lids.

Highyeild:

It may also occur following chronic conjunctivitis, chronic blepharitis, and due to any cause of ectropion .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Punctal obstruction : There may be a congenital absence of puncta or cicatricial closure following injuries, burns, or infections. Rarely, a small foreign body, concretion, or cilia may also block the punctum. Prolonged use of drugs like idoxuridine and pilocarpine is also associated with punctal stenosis. Option: C. Congenital lesions of the nasolacrimal duct that may lead to epiphora include non canalization, partial canalization, or imperforated membranous valves. Acquired causes of obstruction are traumatic strictures, inflammatory strictures, idiopathic stenosis, tumors, and diseases of the surrounding bones. Option: D. Canalicular obstruction may be congenital or acquired due to foreign body, trauma, idiopathic fibrosis and canaliculitis thus causing epiphora. Commonest cause of canaliculitis is actinomyces.

Extraedge:

Mechanical obstruction in lacrimal passages may lie at the level of the punctum, canaliculus, lacrimal, sac, or nasolacrimal duct.

questions.text: A patient presents with a watering eye. Which of the following statements are true about the clinical evaluation?

options.label: A
options.text: Reflux of mucopurulent discharge during regurgitation test indicates acute dacryocystitis.

options.label: B
options.text: Normally, the dye should be seen in the conjunctival sac during FDDT.

options.label: C
options.text: A free passage of saline into the nose during the lacrimal syringing test rules out any mechanical obstruction

options.label: D
options.text: Jones dye tests are performed when a complete obstruction is suspected

questions.correct_answer: C. A free passage of saline into the nose during the lacrimal syringing test rules out any mechanical obstruction
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A free passage of saline into the nose during the lacrimal syringing test rules out any mechanical obstruction The lacrimal syringing test is performed after topical anesthesia with 4% xylocaine . Normal saline is pushed into the lacrimal sac from the lower punctum with the help of a syringe and lacrimal cannula.

Highyeild:

A free passage of saline through lacrimal passages into the nose rules out any mechanical obstruction.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- O ption: A. Regurgitation test : A steady pressure with the index finger is applied over the lacrimal sac area above the medial palpebral ligament. Reflux of mucopurulent discharge indicates chronic dacryocystitis with obstruction at the lower end of the sac or the nasolacrimal duct. Option: B. Fluorescein dye disappearance test (FDDT): In this test 2 drops of fluorescein dye are instilled in both the conjunctival sacs and observations are made after 2 minutes. Normally, no dye is seen in the conjunctival sac. Prolonged retention of dye in the conjunctival sac indicates inadequate drainage which may be due to atonia of the sac or mechanical obstruction. Option: D. Jones dye tests are performed when a partial obstruction is suspected. Jones dye tests are of no value in the presence of total obstruction.

questions.text: Match the clinical features of chronic dacryocystitis with their respective stages' Select the correct answer from the given below ciode:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a Chronic dacryocystitis is more common than acute The etiology of chronic dacryocystitis is multifactorial . Clinical features of chronic dacryocystitis may be divided into four stages: Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis Stage of lacrimal mucocele Stage of chronic suppurative dacryocystitis Stage of chronic fibrotic sac

Random:

Explanation for all options:- Option: A. Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis: It is characterized by mild inflammation of the lacrimal sac associated with blockage of NLD. Watering eyes is the only symptom in this stage and sometimes mild redness in the inner canthus. On syringing the lacrimal sac, either clear fluid or a few fibrinous mucoid flakes regurgitate. Dacryo cystography reveals a block in NLD, a normal-sized lacrimal sac with healthy mucosa. Option: B. Stage of lacrimal mucocele : It follows chronic stagnation causing distension of the lacrimal sac. Characteristic features include constant epiphora associated with a swelling just below the inner canthus Dacryo cystography at this stage reveals a distended sac with blockage somewhere in the NLD Option: C. Stage of chronic suppurative dacryocystitis: Due to pyogenic infection, the mucoid discharge becomes purulent, converting the mucocele into ‘ proceed ’. The condition is characterized by epiphora, associated recurrent conjunctivitis, and swelling at the inner canthus with mild erythema of the overlying skin. On regurgitation, a frank purulent discharge flows from the lower punctum. Option: D. Stage of the chronic fibrotic sac. : Low-grade repeated infections for a prolonged period ultimately result in a small fibrotic sac due to the thickening of the mucosa , which is often associated with persistent epiphora and discharge. Dacryo cystography at this stage reveals a very small sac with irregular folds in the mucosa

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the given Image are incorrect:

options.label: A
options.text: C passes vertically from the lid margin for about 2 mm

options.label: B
options.text: A small flap of mucosa overhangs the junction of the B and D

options.label: D
options.text: E opens into the middle nasal meatus

questions.correct_answer: D. E opens into the middle nasal meatus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

E opens into the middle nasal meatus The nasolacrimal duct is 12–18 mm long and is the inferior continuation of the lacrimal sac . It descends and angles slightly laterally and posteriorly to open into the inferior nasal meatus, lateral to and below the inferior turbinate.

Highyeild:

The Image of lacrimal apparatus is given here.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . The canaliculi pass vertically from the lid margin for about 2 mm (ampullae). They then turn medially and run horizontally for about 8 mm to reach the lacrimal sac. Option: B. A small flap of mucosa (Rosenmuller valve) overhangs the junction of the common canaliculus and the lacrimal sac (the internal punctum) and prevents the reflux of tears into the canaliculi. Option: C. The lacrimal sac is 10–12 mm long and lies in the lacrimal fossa between the anterior and posterior lacrimal crests. The lacrimal bone and the frontal process of the maxilla separate the lacrimal sac from the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.

questions.text: An external exam was done on patients who came in with Epiphora. Match the following findings in these patients' Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-4, B-5, C-2 Option: A. Ectropion , either localized to the punctal region or involving the wider lid, is often associated with secondary stenosis and thus leads to epiphora,

Random:

Explanation for other options:- Option: B. A pouting punctum is typical of canaliculitis. Option: C. Punctal stenosis is extremely common and has been reported as present in up to about half of the general population. Over half of the patients with evident stenosis are asymptomatic, in many cases due to insufficiency of tear production or increased evaporation. Option: D. Punctal obstruction , usually partial, by a fold of redundant conjunctiva (Conjunctivochalasis) is common but underdiagnosed. Option: E. A large caruncle may displace the punctum away from the globe thus causing epiphora.

questions.text: Match the characteristics of the following diseases of the lacrimal gland with the respective disease processes.' Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a- 2 / b- 3 / c- 1 Mikulicz syndrome is characterized by symmetrical enlargement of the lacrimal and salivary glands. The etiology varies but the swelling is usually of a lymphomatous nature. Both parotid and lacrimal glands are enlarged in uveoparotid

Highyeild:

Chronic dacryocystitis is more common than acute dacryocystitis. The etiology of chronic dacryocystitis is multifactorial . Clinical features of chronic dacryocystitis may be divided into four stages: Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis Stage of lacrimal mucocele Stage of chronic suppurative dacryocystitis Stage of chronic fibrotic sac

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Dacryops is a cystic swelling in the upper fornix due to retention of secretion following blockage of one of the lacrimal ducts. It can be distinguished from retention cysts of Krause glands only by its position. Option: C. Congenital dacryocystitis is almost always chronic , while acquired dacryocystitis may be acute or chronic. Ethmoidal infections are frequently associated with dacryocystitis.

questions.text: A 5-day-old female came in with epiphora and swelling at the site of the lacrimal sac. On exam, you notice that on pressure over the sac, mucopus or pus regurgitates through the puncta. Which of the following statements is not true about this patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: If this goes untreated, tends to progress and the walls of the sac ultimately become atonic

options.label: B
options.text: Congenital disease is due to complete canalization of the lacrimal system

options.label: C
options.text: It may lead to preseptal cellulitis

options.label: D
options.text: Nasal polyps may cause a similar set of symptoms in older children and adults.

questions.correct_answer: B. Congenital disease is due to complete canalization of the lacrimal system
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Congenital disease is due to complete canalization of the lacrimal system The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Congenital dacryocystitis. Inflammation of the lacrimal sac is known as dacryocystitis. It generally affects two age groups, infants and adult females older than 40 years.

Highyeild:

Congenital dacryocystitis is almost always chronic, while acquired dacryocystitis may be acute or chronic. Congenital dacryocystitis is due to incomplete canalization of the lacrimal system, most often at the valve of Hasner.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Untreated chronic dacryocystitis never undergoes spontaneous resolution. The condition tends to progress and the walls of the sac ultimately become atonic, the contents never being evacuated except by external pressure. Option: C. Congenital dacryocystitis needs aggressive therapy as the infection can spread to become preseptal cellulitis and rarely orbital cellulitis, leading further to even meningitis. Option: D. Obstruction to the lower end of the nasal duct may also be caused by the pressure of nasal polypi, a hypertrophied inferior turbinate bone, or extreme deviation of the septum. This accumulation of secretions and tears within the lacrimal sac is easily infected.

Extraedge:

In the newborn , antibiotic drops, sac massage (b.d./t.i.d.), and eye hygiene are advised.

questions.text: A 5-day-old female came in with epiphora and swelling at the site of the lacrimal sac. On exam, you notice that on pressure over the sac, mucopus or pus regurgitates through the puncta. Which of the following are appropriate management strategies for this patient’s condition Massaging downwards and medially Antibiotic drops Therapeutic syringing and probing of nasolacrimal duct Nasal endoscopy Eye hygiene Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a,b, and e The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Congenital dacryocystitis . Inflammation of the lacrimal sac is known as dacryocystitis. It generally affects two age groups, infants and adult females older than 40 years. Congenital dacryocystitis is almost always chronic, while acquired dacryocystitis may be acute or chronic.

Highyeild:

Congenital dacryocystitis is due to incomplete canalization of the lacrimal system, most often at the valve of Hasner. In the newborn, antibiotic drops, sac massage (b.d./t.i.d.), and eye hygiene are advised .

Random:

Explanation for all options:- Option: A. Hydrostatic pressure is applied by massaging downwards and medially with a clean thumb behind the anterior lacrimal crest. Option: B. Congenital dacryocystitis needs aggressive therapy as the infection can spread to become preseptal cellulitis and rarely orbital cellulitis, leading further to even meningitis. In purulent or mucopurulent discharge, samples should be sent for bacterial culture and sensitivity. Option: C. Congenital dacryocystitis needs aggressive therapy as the infection can spread to become preseptal cellulitis and rarely orbital cellulitis, leading further to even meningitis. If, however, 9 months to 1 year elapses without marked improvement , therapeutic syringing and probing of the nasolacrimal duct through the upper canaliculus should be carried out in general anesthesia. The greatest care has to be exercised to avoid injuring the walls of the duct. Option: D. Use of the nasal endoscope for direct visualization of the terminal end of the obstructed nasolacrimal duct/probe and the presence of inferior turbinate hypertrophy has improved the overall success of primary therapeutic probing in congenital cases. However, it is preferred only in cases where the initial conservative management has been exhausted. Option: E. Eye hygiene is an obvious and mandatory part of the management of this condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female came in with profuse watering for one and a half weeks. On exam, you notice nasal septum deviation due to past accidents and mucocele near the lacrimal sac. There is no redness or edema. Which of these is an incorrect statement?

options.label: A
options.text: The site of involvement is usually at the junction of the nasolacrimal duct and sac

options.label: B
options.text: The patient is experiencing these symptoms due to obstruction to the upper end of the nasal duct.

options.label: C
options.text: Untreated conditions will never undergo spontaneous resolution.

questions.correct_answer: B. The patient is experiencing these symptoms due to obstruction to the upper end of the nasal duct.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The patient is experiencing these symptoms due to obstruction to the upper end of the nasal duct. The given case history and findings point toward the diagnosis of Dacryocystitis . It generally affects two age groups, infants and adult females older than 40 years. The essential symptom is epiphora , aggravated by such conditions as exposure to wind. There may be a swelling at the site of the sac (a mucocele) and the caruncle and neighboring parts of the conjunctiva are frequently inflamed. On pressure over the sac, mucopus or pus regurgitates through the puncta, or more rarely passes down into the nose.

Highyeild:

Obstruction to the lower end of the nasal duct may also be caused by the pressure of the nasal polypi, a hypertrophied inferior turbinate bone, or extreme deviation of the septum.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. In adults, the obstruction is usually at the junction of the nasolacrimal duct and sac for which permanent drainage into the nose by dacryocystorhinostomy must be performed. Option: C. Untreated chronic dacryocystitis never undergoes spontaneous resolution. The condition tends to progress and the walls of the sac ultimately become atonic, the contents never being evacuated except by external pressure. Option: D. The accumulation of secretions and tears within the lacrimal sac is easily infected. Ethmoidal infections are frequently associated with dacryocystitis.

Extraedge:

Chronic dacryocystitis is more common than acute dacryocystitis. The etiology of chronic dacryocystitis is multifactorial. Clinical features of chronic dacryocystitis may be divided into four stages: Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis Stage of lacrimal mucocele Stage of chronic suppurative dacryocystitis Stage of chronic fibrotic sac

questions.text: Canalicular obstruction can be a side effect of all of the following except
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Latanoprost Epiphora is an overflow of tears due to inadequate drainage of normally secreted tears Causes Physiological cause due to lower eyelid laxity or weakness of orbicularis muscle Mechanical obstruction may be at the level of punctum, canaliculus, lacrimal sac or nasolacrimal duct

Highyeild:

Investigations: Ocular examination with diffuse illumination using magnification Regurgitation test - reflux of mucopurulent discharge indicates chronic dacryocystitis with obstruction at the lower end of sac Fluorescein dye disappearance test- fluorescein is instilled 2 drops in both conjunctival sacs and observed for 2 mins. No dye is seen in the sac. Prolonged retention of dye in the sac indicates inadequate drainage Lacrimal syringe test- normal saline is pushed into the sac from the lower punctum with the help of a syringe and lacrimal cannula A free passage of saline through the lacrimal passage into the nose rules out mechanical obstruction Presence of partial obstruction, saline passes with considerable pressure Presence of obstruction no fluid passes into the nose and it may reflux through same punctum

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Idoxuridine- Idoxuridine is an anti-herpesvirus antiviral drug . It is a nucleoside analog, a modified form of deoxyuridine, similar enough to be incorporated into viral DNA replication, but the iodine atom added to the uracil component blocks base pairing. It is used only topically due to cardiotoxicity . Option: B. 5-FU- Fluorouracil , sold under the brand name Adrucil among others, is a cytotoxic chemotherapy medication used to treat cancer. Intravenous injection is used for the treatment of colorectal cancer, oesophageal cancer, stomach cancer, pancreatic cancer, breast cancer, and cervical cancer. Option: C. Phospholine iodide - This medication is used to treat high pressure inside the eye (due to conditions such as certain types of glaucoma) and other eye problems (such as accommodative esotropia). It works by causing the pupil to shrink , decreasing the amount of fluid within the eye, and affecting certain eye muscles.

Extraedge:

Other Investigation: Jones dye test- 2% fluorescein dye instilled into the conjunctival sac and after 5 mins a cotton bud soaked in anesthetic is placed at the opening of NLD If positive, indicates patent drainage, watering due to hypersecretion If negative, no staining seen on the bed. Partial obstruction or lacrimal pump failure this can be differentiated by Jones dye test 2 residual fluorescein is washed out by irrigation and bud placed If positive, fluorescein staining seen indicates partial obstruction If negative, no staining seen indicates lacrimal pump failure Dacrocystography Radio nucleotide dacrocystography

questions.text: Which is the most common epithelial lacrimal gland tumor?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pleomorphic adenoma Pleomorphic adenoma (benign mixed tumor) is the most common epithelial neoplasm of the lacrimal gland. It is usually a slow-growing , well-circumscribed Patients generally have an excellent prognosis for vision and long-term survival after complete surgical excision. There is a tendency to recur, especially if there is an incomplete excision, and rarely, malignant transformation to carcinoma pleomorphic adenoma can occur, which has a much poorer prognosis.

Highyeild:

Patients commonly present with slight fullness in the temporal upper lid, to those with frank proptosis, diplopia, visual impairment, and eyeball displacement .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: D . Presence of the tumor, at or near the lacrimal fossa bone, the enlarging tumor displaces the eye downward and nasally. The duration of symptoms is a very important clinical indicator of a PA. The suspicion of malignancy increases when the symptoms have been less than 10 months. Option: A and C . Additionally, sensory loss and pain when present, should raise concern for a malignant neoplasm such as adenoid cystic carcinoma or mucoepidermoid carcinoma .

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the phenol red test for dry eye?

options.label: B
options.text: It measures the volume of tears based on the length of color change in thread

options.label: C
options.text: If the color changes to blue, it depicts mucin deficiency

questions.correct_answer: B. It measures the volume of tears based on the length of color change in thread
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It measures the volume of tears based on the length of color change in thread Inadequate tear production in the elderly Xerophthalmia Sjogren’s syndrome Trachoma decreases the mucin layer Collagen vascular diseases Drugs such as diuretics, decongestants, antihypertensives, etc Sarcoidosis Post LASIK Classification: Aqueous tear-deficient dry eye Sjogren’s syndrome dry eye Non-Sjogren syndrome dry eye Primary lacrimal gland deficiencies Secondary lacrimal gland deficiencies Obstruction of the lacrimal gland ducts Reflex hyposecretion Reflex sensory block Reflex motor block Evaporative dry eye Intrinsic causes Meibomian gland dysfunction Disorders of lid aperture and lid/globe congruity or dynamics Low blink rate Extrinsic causes Ocular surface disorders Contact lens wear Ocular surface disease Allergic conjunctivitis

Highyeild:

Investigation - The tear film stained with sodium fluorescein 1% is observed with a slit-lamp and the time noted after instructing the patient to blink. The time taken for the first appearance of a ‘dark’ dry spot is recorded as the ‘tear-film breakup time’ or ‘TBUT’ . A tear film break-up time of fewer than 10 seconds suggests a dry eye with mucin deficiency. Rose Bengal 1% or lissamine green which stains devitalized, desiccated corneal and conjunctival epithelium red or green. It is very useful for detecting even mild cases of KCS . Depending upon the severity of KCS three staining patterns A, B, and C have been described.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Indicates severe cases with confluent staining of conjunctiva and cornea A tear: lysozyme ratio between 0.9 and 0.6 or Schirmer tests producing wetting of less than 6 mm support the diagnosis. Option: B . Indicates moderate cases with extensive staining Option: C. Represents mild case with fine punctate stains in interpalpebral area

Extraedge:

Rx- Supplementation with tear substitutes Topical cyclosporine Treat the causative agent

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with watering in his right eye for 1 year. Syringing revealed a patent drainage system Rest of the ocular examination was a normal provisional diagnosis of lacrimal pump failure was made. Confirmation of the diagnosis is done by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dacryoscintigraphy Epiphora is overflow of tears due to inadequate drainage of normally secreted tears Causes Physiological cause due to lower eyelid laxity or weakness of orbicularis muscle Mechanical obstruction may be at the level of punctum, canaliculus, lacrimal sac or nasolacrimal duct

Highyeild:

Investigations: Ocular examination with diffuse illumination using magnification

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Regurgitation test - reflux of mucopurulent discharge indicates chronic dacryocystitis with obstruction at lower end of sac. Fluorescein dye disappearance test - fluorescein is instilled 2 drops in both conjunctival sacs and observed for 2 mins. No dye is seen in the Prolonged retention of dye in the sac indicates inadequate drainage. Option: C . Lacrimal syringe test - normal saline is pushed into the sac from the lower punctum with the help of a syringe and lacrimal cannula A free passage of saline through the lacrimal passage into the nose rules out mechanical obstruction Presence of partial obstruction, saline passes with considerable pressure Option: D . Presence of obstruction no fluid passes into the nose and it may reflux through same punctum

Extraedge:

Jones dye test- 2% fluorescein dye instilled into the conjunctival sac and after 5 mins a cotton bud soaked in anesthetic is placed at the opening of NLD If positive, indicates patent drainage, watering due to hypersecretion If negative, no staining seen on the Partial obstruction of lacrimal pump failure can be differentiated by Jones dye test 2 residual fluorescein is washed out by irrigation and bud placed If positive, fluorescein staining seen indicates partial obstruction If negative, no staining seen indicates lacrimal pump failure Dacrocystography Dacryoscintigraphy confirms the diagnosis Radionucleotide dacrocystography

questions.text: In common canalicular blockage, which is true about Jones test findings?

options.label: A
options.text: First test positive second test negative

options.label: B
options.text: First test negative second test positive

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both negative Epiphora is an overflow of tears due to inadequate drainage of normally secreted tears Causes Physiological cause due to lower eyelid laxity or weakness of orbicularis muscle Mechanical obstruction may be at the level of punctum, canaliculus, lacrimal sac or nasolacrimal duct

Highyeild:

Investigations: Ocular examination with diffuse illumination using magnification Regurgitation test - reflux of mucopurulent discharge indicates chronic dacryocystitis with obstruction at lower end of sac Fluorescein dye disappearance test- fluorescein is instilled 2 drops in both conjunctival sac and observed for 2 mins. No dye is seen in the sac. Prolonged retention of dye in the sac indicates inadequate drainage Lacrimal syringe test- normal saline is pushed into the sac from the lower punctum with the help of a syringe and lacrimal cannula A free passage of saline through the lacrimal passage into the nose rules out mechanical obstruction Presence of partial obstruction, saline passes with considerable pressure Presence of obstruction no fluid passes into the nose and it may reflux through same punctum

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- If positive , indicates patent drainage, and watering due to hypersecretion So, Options A, B, and C are not the correct choices If negative , no staining is seen on the Partial obstruction of lacrimal pump failure this can be differentiated by Jones dye test 2 residual fluorescein is washed out by irrigation and bud placed If positive, fluorescein staining seen indicates partial obstruction If negative, no staining seen indicates lacrimal pump failure Dacrocystography Radionucleotide dacrocystography

Extraedge:

2% fluorescein dye instilled into the conjunctival sac and after 5 mins a cotton bud soaked in anesthetic is placed at the opening of NLD.

questions.text: Identify the pathology depicted in the given Image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dry Eye Congenital cataract refers to lens opacity presents at birth, developing either during 1st 2 years of life, infantile or later, developmental cataract Types : Zonular/lamellar cataract Punctate cataract Anterior pole cataract Posterior pole cataract Punctate cataract Coronary cataract

Highyeild:

Rx Based on density its treated, if U/L dense urgent surgery to reduce risk of amblyopia If B/L dense cataract, early surgery within 4- 6 weeks of life

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Hypopyon - Hypopyon—layering of white blood cells in the anterior chamber—signifies severe anterior segment intraocular inflammation . The frequency of hypopyon has been described in two small to moderate-sized series of patients with various types of uveitis. Option: C. Seclusio pupillae- Seclusio pupillae occurs when the synechiae extend 360 degrees around the pupillary Peripheral anterior synechiae may lead to secondary angle-closure glaucoma if they fuse circumferentially and are typically found inferiorly. PAS is more often found superiorly when associated with primary angle closure. Option: D. Posterior subcapsular cataract - A posterior subcapsular cataract starts as a small, opaque area that usually forms near the back of the lens, right in the path of light. A posterior subcapsular cataract often interferes with your reading vision, reduces your vision in bright light, and causes glare or halos around lights at night.

Extraedge:

Indications for surgery in pediatric group Dense cataract > 3mm in diameter, covering the visual axis Pupil doesn’t dilate Squint/ nystagmus is seen to develop Lens aspiration with anterior vitrectomy with posterior capsulorhexis and IOL implantation Extracapsular cataract extraction techniques are the choice

questions.text: Name the surgical procedure shown in the below image.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Frontalis sling Frontalis slings are one surgical approach to the repair of a droopy eyelid or ptosis (TOE-sis). Ptosis occurs when the muscles that lift the eye are diseased or stretched out. The vast majority of people with ptosis develop it as adults as part of the natural aging process . In these individuals, the muscle still works, but because it has stretched out with age, the lid is lower at rest and it takes more effort to keep the lid high enough to see out your eye.

Highyeild:

Surgery to fix this condition involves tightening or shortening this muscle in order to raise the lid's resting position.

Random:

Explanation for all options:- Option: A. Fasanella-Servat procedure Indicated for mild ptosis (1.5-2mm) with good levator function Excision of upper border of tarsus, lower border of Muller muscle and overlying conjunctiva Option B. Jones procedure JONES PROCEDURE Plication of lower eyelid retractors thus increasing their pull and creating the barrier between preseptal and pretarsal portions of orbicularis Performed in recurrent cases.

questions.text: Amrita, the mother of a 5-day-old baby, brought her baby to the hospital with complaints of excessive watering in the left eye. On examination, a block in the nasolacrimal duct was found. Which of the following is the appropriate mode of treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Massage over the lacrimal sac area and topical antibiotics.

options.label: B
options.text: Probing of NLD with Bowman’s probe.

questions.correct_answer: A. Massage over the lacrimal sac area and topical antibiotics.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Massage over the lacrimal sac area and topical antibiotics. Massage over the lacrimal sac area and topical antibiotics constitute the treatment of congenital NLD block , up to 6-8 weeks of age.

Highyeild:

The nasolacrimal duct is 12–18 mm long and is the inferior continuation of the lacrimal sac . It descends and angles slightly laterally and posteriorly to open into the inferior nasal meatus, lateral to and below the inferior turbinate. Fasanella-Servat procedure

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Massage increases the hydrostatic pressure in the sac and helps to open up the membranous occlusions. Option: C . It should be carried out at least 4 times a day to be followed by the instillation of antibiotic drops. Option: D . This conservative treatment cures obstruction in about 90 percent of infants. It should be performed in case the condition is not cured by the age of 3-4 months. Balloon catheter dilatation may be carried out where repeated probing is a failure. Intubations with silicone tubes may be performed if repeated probings are a failure.

Extraedge:

The Image of lacrimal apparatus is given here.

questions.text: You are conducting retrospective research on factors responsible for a dry eye disorder. As a part of your studies, you are looking through the files in the clinic of dry eye patients. Which among the following patients would not be included in your study?

options.label: A
options.text: 12 years old patient with Schirmer test value of 26mm.

options.label: B
options.text: 20 years old patient showing tear film break up at 20 seconds.

options.label: C
options.text: 22 years old patient with Schirmer test value of 20mm.

options.label: D
options.text: 22 years old patient showing Schirmer test strip wet up to 9mm

questions.correct_answer: B. 20 years old patient showing tear film break up at 20 seconds.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

20 years old patient showing tear film break up at 20 seconds. Normal values of the Schirmer-I test are more than 15 mm . Hence the patient does not suffer from dry eyes.

Highyeild:

Lacrimal tests includes tear film break up time (TFBUT) for any eye and Jane’s test for watering eye. TFBUT measurement is an easy and fast method used to assess the stability of tear film. It is a standard diagnostic procedure in the dry eye clinics. Tear film break-up time is abnormal in several conditions like aqueous tear deficiency [2], keratoconjunctivitis sicca, mucin deficiency, and meibomian gland disorders

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Tear film break up test - Its normal values range from 15 to 35 seconds. Values less than 10 seconds imply an unstable tear film. This patient has a value of 20 seconds. Since he has a stable tear film and cannot be included in the study. Option: C . Normal values of the Schirmer-I test are more than 15 mm. Hence the patient does not suffer from dry eyes. Option: D . Normal values of the Schirmer-I test are more than 15 mm. Values of 5-10 mm are suggestive of moderate to mild keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS) and less than 5 mm of severe KCS. Hence a value of 9mm indicates dry eye.

questions.text: Identify the test shown below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schirmer test It is the interval between a complete blink and the appearance of the first randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. It is noted after instilling a drop of fluorescein and examining in a cobalt-blue light of a slit-lamp. BUT is an indicator of the adequacy of the mucin component of tears. Its normal values range from 15 to 35 seconds .

Highyeild:

Values less than 10 seconds imply an unstable tear film. It measures total tear secretions . It is performed with the help of a 5 × 35 mm strip of Whatman-41 filter paper which is folded 5 mm from one end and kept in the lower fornix at the junction of lateral one-third and medial two-thirds. The patient is asked to look up and not to blink or close the eyes after 5 minutes wetting of the filter paper strip from the bent end is measured. Normal values of the Schirmer-I test are more than 15 mm.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Values of 5-10 mm are suggestive of moderate to mild keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS) and less than 5 mm of severe KCS. It is a very useful test for detecting even mild cases of KCS. Depending upon the severity of KCS three staining patterns Abreaksnd C have been described: Option: C. pattern represents mild or early cases with fine punctate stains in the interpalpebral area; Option: B . the moderate cases with extensive staining; and 'A' the severe cases with confluent staining of conjunctiva and cornea. This test detects osmolarity which is an indicator for dry eye disease.

questions.text: A 1-year-old male child was brought to the opd with complaints of watering in the eye for the past 5 days which turned mucopurulent today. There is associated swelling of the lacrimal sac area. What is the cause of this change?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Secondary bacterial infection The stasis of secretions in the lacrimal sac due to obstruction of NLD predisposes to secondary bacterial infection.

Highyeild:

The nasolacrimal duct is 12–18 mm long and is the inferior continuation of the lacrimal sac . It descends and angles slightly laterally and posteriorly to open into the inferior nasal meatus, lateral to and below the inferior turbinate.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Viral infection does not present with mucopurulent discharge Mucopurulent discharge is most commonly seen in untreated dacryocystitis. Option: C . Fungal infection of the sac is rarely seen only in cases of immunocompromised children. Option: D . Parasitic infections don't cause a mucopurulent discharge.

Extraedge:

Massage over the lacrimal sac area and topical antibiotics constitute the treatment of congenital NLD block , up to 6-8 weeks of age.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dacryoadenitis Dacryoadenitis is the inflammation of the lacrimal gland. The upper eyelid becomes s-shaped as shown in the picture.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Dacryocystitis is the inflammation of the lacrimal sac. Swelling is near the medial aspect of the eye. Option: C . Chalazion is swelling of the meibomian gland and most commonly occurs in the upper eyelid away from the lid margin. Option: D . Ptosis is the drooping of the upper eyelid and does not present as swelling.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of tear film?

options.label: A
options.text: Moisten surface of cornea and conjunctiva.

options.label: C
options.text: Facilitates movement of lids over the globe

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hydration of cornea Tear film acts as a lubricant and moistens conjunctiva and cornea. TFBUT measurement is an easy and fast method used to assess the stability of tear film. It is a standard diagnostic procedure in dry eye clinics.

Highyeild:

Tear film break-up time is abnormal in several conditions like aqueous tear deficiency [2], keratoconjunctivitis sicca, mucin deficiency, and meibomian gland disorders

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Corneal epithelium prevents entry of tears into the stroma thereby maintaining corneal transparency. Oxygen is supplied to the cornea from tear film by diffusion. Option: C . Because of its lubricant nature it facilitates movement over the globe. Option: D . Tear contains lysozyme and other antibacterial products which prevent infection.

Extraedge:

Tear film break-up test - Its normal values range from 15 to 35 seconds. Values less than 10 seconds imply an unstable tear film. This patient has a value of 20 seconds. Since he has a stable tear film and cannot be included in the study.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male came with complaints of watering in the left eye for the past 1 day. He also gives a history of dust entering his eye while driving and foreign body sensations prior to the start of watering. You suspect a foreign body in the nasolacrimal system. On probing a soft stop was felt at around 10mm from the punctum. Which of the following is most likely the site of the block?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Common canaliculus A hard stop on probing indicates obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct . A soft stop at 5-8mm indicates a block in the upper or lower canaliculi A soft stop beyond 8mm indicates a block in the common canaliculus .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Nasolacrimal duct Option: B . Upper Canaliculus Option: C . Lower Canaliculus

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bowman’s lacrimal probe

questions.text: A 43-year-old male came with complaints of grittiness in the eye for the past 5 days. A tear film breakup test was done. Which of the following is true about the test?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the Time between the first blink and the first dry spot

options.label: B
options.text: It is the time between the last blink and the last dry spot

options.label: C
options.text: It is the time between the first blink and the first wet spot

options.label: D
options.text: It is the time between the last blink and the last wet spot

questions.correct_answer: A. It is the Time between the first blink and the first dry spot
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is the Time between the first blink and the first dry spot After the application of 2% fluorescein dye, the patient is asked to blink. In the dry eye, the time after 1 st blink and the appearance of the dry spot is called tear film breakup time . Tear film breakup time is the time between the blink and appearance of the first dry spot. There is no wet spot in the dry Applanation tonometry is the most frequent procedure in which tear film is stained. Lacrimal tests include tear film break up time (TBUT) for any eye and Jane’s test for watering the eye.

Highyeild:

TFBUT measurement is an easy and fast method used to assess the stability of tear film. It is a standard diagnostic procedure in dry eye clinics. Tear film break-up time is abnormal in several conditions like aqueous tear deficiency [2], keratoconjunctivitis sicca, mucin deficiency, and meibomian gland disorders

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. It is the time between the last blink and the last dry spot - it is not the correct statement. Option: C. It is the time between the first blink and the first wet spot - it is not the correct statement. Option: D. It is the time between the last blink and the last wet spot - it is not the correct statement.

Extraedge:

Tear film break-up test - Its normal values range from 15 to 35 seconds. Values less than 10 seconds imply an unstable tear film. This patient has a value of 20 seconds. Since he has a stable tear film and cannot be included in the study.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient came with complaints of a gritty sensation in the eye. On investigation tear film break-up time was found to be 8 seconds. Which layer of his tear film is deficient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mucous layer A tear film breakup time of < 10 seconds indicates mucin layer deficiency. Mucous layer is the appropriate answer.

Highyeild:

TFBUT measurement is an easy and fast method used to assess the stability of tear film. It is a standard diagnostic procedure in dry eye clinics. Tear film break-up time is abnormal in several conditions like aqueous tear deficiency [2], keratoconjunctivitis sicca, mucin deficiency, and meibomian gland disorders

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. For aqueous layer deficiency or dry eye the investigation done is Schirmer test . Option: C . for lipid layer deficiency tear film break-up time is not a suitable investigation.

Extraedge:

Tear film break-up test - Its normal values range from 15 to 35 seconds. Values less than 10 seconds imply an unstable tear film. This patient has a value of 20 seconds. Since he has a stable tear film and cannot be included in the study.c

questions.text: A 17 years old male student came with complaints of foreign body sensation in the eye while looking at the blackboard for long hours. A tear film breakup time was found to be 7 seconds. Which of these structures is responsible for the secretion of the layer which is deficient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Goblet cells of conjunctiva The Given Patient Suffers From Mucin Layer Deficiency As Indicated By Tear Film Break Up Time Of < 10 Seconds . Goblet cells of conjunctiva secrete the mucous layer.

Highyeild:

TFBUT measurement is an easy and fast method used to assess the stability of tear film. It is a standard diagnostic procedure in dry eye clinics. Tear film break-up time is abnormal in several conditions like aqueous tear deficiency [2], keratoconjunctivitis sicca, mucin deficiency, and meibomian gland disorders

Random:

Explanation for all options:- Option: A . Meibomian gland secretes the lipid layer of the tear film. Option: C . Krause gland is an accessory tear gland. Option: D . Wolfring gland is an accessory tear gland.

Extraedge:

Tear film break-up test - Its normal values range from 15 to 35 seconds. Values less than 10 seconds imply an unstable tear film. This patient has a value of 20 seconds. Since he has a stable tear film and cannot be included in the study.

questions.text: A 35-year-old came with complaints of watering of an eye for the past month. The regurgitation test revealed mucopurulent discharge. Which is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. NLD block and chronic dacryocystitis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NLD block and chronic dacryocystitis The patient complained of water for the past 1 month which indicates a chronic disease. Regurgitation revealed mucopurulent discharge suggesting dacryocystitis with NLD block.

Highyeild:

Chronic dacryocystitis is more common than acute dacryocystitis. The etiology of chronic dacryocystitis is multifactorial . Clinical features of chronic dacryocystitis may be divided into four stages: Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis 2. Stage of lacrimal mucocele 3. Stage of chronic suppurative dacryocystitis 4. Stage of chronic fibrotic sac

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . NLD block alone can't be the answer as it has a mucopurulent discharge and it indicates chronic infection. Option: C . There is mucopurulent discharge so it can't be acute dacryocystitis. Option: D . There is mucopurulent discharge so it can't be acute dacryocystitis.

Extraedge:

Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis: It is characterized by mild inflammation of the lacrimal sac associated with blockage of NLD. Watering eyes is the only symptom in this stage and sometimes mild redness in the inner canthus. On syringing the lacrimal sac, either clear fluid or a few fibrinous mucoid flakes regurgitate. Dacryo cystography reveals a block in NLD, a normal-sized lacrimal sac with healthy mucosa. Stage of lacrimal mucocele : It follows chronic stagnation causing distension of the lacrimal sac. Characteristic features include constant epiphora associated with swelling just below the inner canthus Dacryo cystography at this stage reveals a distended sac with blockage somewhere in the NLD Stage of chronic suppurative dacryocystitis: Due to pyogenic infection, the mucoid discharge becomes purulent, converting the mucocele into ‘pyocele ’. The condition is characterized by epiphora, associated recurrent conjunctivitis, and swelling at the inner canthus with mild erythema of the overlying skin. On regurgitation, a frank purulent discharge flows from the lower punctum. Stage of the chronic fibrotic sac. : Low-grade repeated infections for a prolonged period ultimately result in a small fibrotic sac due to the thickening of the mucosa , which is often associated with persistent epiphora and discharge. Dacryo cystography at this stage reveals a very small sac with irregular folds in the mucosa

questions.text: A 55-year-old female comes with complaints of unilateral watering of the eye. He was evaluated by syringing and probing. Which of the following is used for the punctum dilation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

4% Xylocaine 4% xylocaine is the most widely used local anesthetic in this procedure because of its faster action and complete local anesthesia .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B: 15% xylocaine is not used Option C: 1% xylocaine is not used Option D: 12%xylocaine is not used

questions.text: A 44-year-old male comes with complaints of watering of the eye for the past 20 days. Syringing revealed the presence of a block. Furthermore, Dacryo cystography is done for the confirmation of?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Option: A . Dacryo cystography tells the site, extent, and type of the block. Option: B . Dacryo cystography tells the site, extent, and type of the block. Option: C . Dacryo cystography tells the site, extent, and type of the block. Option: D . Dacryo cystography is valuable in patients with mechanical obstruction.

Highyeild:

It tells the exact size, nature, and extent of the block . In addition, it also gives information about the mucosa of the sac, and the presence of any fistulae, diverticula, stones, or tumors in the sac.

questions.text: An intern posted in the ophthalmology department. A senior resident posted there asked him about the layers of the tear film. Which of the following layers of tear film consists of antibacterial substances?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aqueous layer Wolff was the first to describe the detailed structure of the fluid covering the cornea and called it precorneal film . He described this film to consist of three layers , which from posterior to anterior are the mucus layer, aqueous layer, and lipid or oily layer. Aqueous layer. The bulk of tear film (7.0 um) is formed by this intermediate layer which consists of tears secreted by the main and accessory lacrimal glands .

Highyeild:

The tears mainly comprise water and small quantities of solutes such as sodium chloride, sugar, urea, and proteins. Therefore, it is alkaline and salty in taste. It also contains antibacterial substances like beta-lysin and lactoferrin.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Mucus layer. It is the innermost and about 0.2 µm thick stratum of the tear film. It consists of mucin secreted by conjunctival goblet cells and glands of Manz . It converts the hydrophobic corneal surface into a hydrophilic one. Option: C and D . Lipid or oily layer . This is the outermost and thinnest (0.1 µm) layer of tear film formed at the air-tear interface from the secretions of meibomian, zeis, and moll glands. This layer prevents the overflow of tears , retards their evaporation, and lubricates the eyelids as they slide over the surface of the globe.

Extraedge:

Tear film break-up test - Its normal values range from 15 to 35 seconds. Values less than 10 seconds imply an unstable tear film. This patient has a value of 20 seconds. Since he has a stable tear film and cannot be included in the study.

questions.text: The length of nasolacrimal duct os
questions.explanation:
Solution:

12-18mm The puncta are openings on the lid margin. Each canaliculus (superior and inferior) has two parts: Vertical (2 mm) and Horizontal (8 mm) The superior and inferior canaliculi usually unite to form the common canaliculus, which opens into the lateral wall of the lacrimal sac.

Highyeild:

A small flap of mucosa (Rosenmüller valve) overhangs the junction of the common canaliculus and the lacrimal sac and prevents the reflux of tears into the canaliculi.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . The lacrimal sac is 10-12 mm long and lies in the lacrimal fossa, between the anterior and posterior lacrimal crests. The lacrimal bone and the frontal process of the maxilla separate the lacrimal sac from the middle meatus of the nasal cavity. Option: C and D .The nasolacrimal duct is 12-18 mm long and is directed downwards, backward, and laterally. The opening of the duct into the inferior meatus is partially covered by a mucosal fold (valve of Hasner).

Extraedge:

The Image of lacrimal apparatus is given here.

questions.text: Sharanamma, 62 years old presented to OPD . She was diagnosed with Chronic dacryocystitis. All the conservative methods were tried and was being counselled for surgical treatment. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dacrocystorhinostomy The treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) as it re-establishes the lacrimal drainage. One of the sequelae of chronic dacryocystitis is mucocele formation, which when infected, leads to pyocele formation and finally lacrimal fibrosis . The Treatment of lacrimal sac fibrosis is dacryocystectomy.

Highyeild:

Chronic dacryocystitis is more common than acute dacryocystitis. The etiology of chronic dacryocystitis is multifactorial . Clinical features of chronic dacryocystitis may be divided into four stages: Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis Stage of lacrimal mucocele Stage of chronic suppurative dacryocystitis Stage of chronic fibrotic sac

Extraedge:

Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis: It is characterized by mild inflammation of the lacrimal sac associated with blockage of NLD. Watering eyes is the only symptom in this stage and sometimes mild redness in the inner canthus. On syringing the lacrimal sac, either clear fluid or a few fibrinous mucoid flakes regurgitate. Dacryo cystography reveals a block in NLD, a normal-sized lacrimal sac with healthy mucosa. Stage of lacrimal mucocele : It follows chronic stagnation causing distension of the lacrimal sac. Characteristic features include constant epiphora associated with swelling just below the inner canthus Dacryo cystography at this stage reveals a distended sac with blockage somewhere in the NLD Stage of chronic suppurative dacryocystitis: Due to pyogenic infection, the mucoid discharge becomes purulent, converting the mucocele into ‘pyocele ’. The condition is characterized by epiphora, associated recurrent conjunctivitis, and swelling at the inner canthus with mild erythema of the overlying skin. On regurgitation, a frank purulent discharge flows from the lower punctum. Stage of the chronic fibrotic sac. : Low-grade repeated infections for a prolonged period ultimately result in a small fibrotic sac due to the thickening of the mucosa , which is often associated with persistent epiphora and discharge. Dacryo cystography at this stage reveals a very small sac with irregular folds in the mucosa

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Sjorgens syndrome?

options.label: C
options.text: On pathology, there's an accumulation of macrophages and neutrophils

options.label: D
options.text: Secondary Sjorgens syndrome is associated with Rheumatoid arthritis

questions.correct_answer: C. On pathology, there's an accumulation of macrophages and neutrophils
questions.explanation:
Solution:

On pathology, there's an accumulation of macrophages and neutrophils Etiology: It is an autoimmune chronic inflammatory disease with multisystem involvement. It typically occurs in women between 40 and 50 years of age. A characteristic feature is an aqueous deficiency of dry eye-the keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS). In primary Sjogren's syndrome patients present with sicca complex-a combination of KCS and xerostomia (dryness of the mouth). In secondary Sjogren's syndrome , dry eye and/or dry mouth are associated with an autoimmune disease, commonly rheumatoid arthritis.

Highyeild:

Pathological features include focal accumulation and infiltration by lymphocytes and plasma cells with the destruction of lacrimal and salivary glandular tissue.
